title: Hosea Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 5.

questions.question: Who does Hosea 5:1 call to hear the message of judgment?
options: Priests, house of Israel, and house of the king
questions.correctAnswer: Priests, house of Israel, and house of the king
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:1 specifically calls the priests, the house of Israel, and the house of the king to hear because judgment is toward them.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:3, what sin does Ephraim commit?
questions.correctAnswer: Whoredom
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:3 states that Ephraim commits whoredom and Israel is defiled.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:6, what do they seek with their flocks and herds?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:6 says they shall go with their flocks and herds to seek the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 5:4 says the people have known the LORD and turned to Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:4 states that they have not known the LORD and have the spirit of whoredoms in the midst of them.

questions.question: What did Hosea 5:7 say the people have begotten?
questions.correctAnswer: Strange children
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:7 states they have begotten strange children, indicating their treacherous dealings against the LORD.

questions.question: Where does Hosea 5:8 command to blow the cornet and trumpet?
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeah and Ramah
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:8 commands to blow the cornet in Gibeah and the trumpet in Ramah.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 5:9 says Ephraim will be joyful in the day of rebuke.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:9 says Ephraim shall be desolate in the day of rebuke.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:10, what were the princes of Judah like?
options: Like those that remove the bound
questions.correctAnswer: Like those that remove the bound
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:10 compares the princes of Judah to those that remove the bound, implying wrongdoing.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hosea 5:15: 'I will go and return to my place, till they acknowledge their _______, and seek my face.'
questions.correctAnswer: offence
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 states God will return to His place until they acknowledge their offence and seek His face.

questions.question: What will God be to Ephraim according to Hosea 5:14?
options: A lion and a young lion
questions.correctAnswer: A lion and a young lion
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:14 says God will be to Ephraim as a lion and a young lion to the house of Judah.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 5:13 says the Assyrian king was able to heal the wounds of Ephraim and Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:13 says Ephraim sent to the king Jareb of Assyria, but he could not heal or cure their wounds.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:11, why is Ephraim oppressed and broken in judgment?
options: Because he willingly walked after the commandment
questions.correctAnswer: Because he willingly walked after the commandment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:11 states Ephraim is oppressed and broken because he willingly walked after the commandment, implying rebellion.

questions.question: What will God pour out upon the princes of Judah like water, according to Hosea 5:10?
questions.correctAnswer: His wrath
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:10 says God will pour out His wrath like water upon the princes of Judah.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Hosea 5:12: 'Therefore will I be unto Ephraim as a _____, and to the house of Judah as rottenness.'
questions.correctAnswer: moth
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:12 states God will be to Ephraim as a moth and to Judah as rottenness.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:2, what have the revolters been profound to make?
questions.correctAnswer: Slaughter
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:2 says the revolters are profound to make slaughter, despite God's rebuke.

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with pride and refuses to seek God. Based on Hosea 5, what biblical truth would you share about humility and repentance?
options: Pride leads to downfall and separation from God.
God always ignores those who are proud.
Pride is acceptable if you pray occasionally.
God rewards prideful people with blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and separation from God.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:5 shows that the pride of Israel testifies against them, leading to their fall. Verses 6 and 14 explain that God withdraws from the proud and punishes them, teaching the need for humility and repentance.

questions.question: How does Hosea 5 teach us about the importance of faithfulness in marriage and family life?
options: Unfaithfulness causes spiritual defilement and separation from God.
Family issues do not affect spiritual life.
God overlooks unfaithfulness if you attend worship.
Faithfulness is optional in spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Unfaithfulness causes spiritual defilement and separation from God.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:3-4 refers to Ephraim committing whoredom and Israel being defiled, symbolizing unfaithfulness that causes separation from God. This underscores the biblical call to faithfulness in relationships.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to rely on worldly alliances instead of God. According to Hosea 5, what warning can you give?
options: Relying on foreign powers will not heal spiritual wounds.
Worldly alliances always bring peace and healing.
God encourages seeking help from political leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Relying on foreign powers will not heal spiritual wounds.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:13 explains that Ephraim sought help from Assyria and King Jareb but they could not heal or cure their wounds, illustrating that true healing comes only from God.

questions.question: How does Hosea 5 illustrate the consequence of turning away from God despite knowing Him?
options: Turning away leads to judgment and destruction.
God will always protect those who turn away.
Turning away has no real consequences.
God forgets those who reject Him.
questions.correctAnswer: Turning away leads to judgment and destruction.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:4-5 shows that Israel does not return to God and because of their iniquity, both Israel and Judah will fall. This highlights the serious consequences of rejecting God.

questions.question: What does Hosea 5 teach about the importance of sincerely seeking God in times of affliction?
options: God will return when His people acknowledge their offenses and seek Him.
Seeking God is unnecessary during troubles.
Affliction means God has abandoned His people forever.
questions.correctAnswer: God will return when His people acknowledge their offenses and seek Him.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 teaches that God will go back to His place until they acknowledge their offense and seek Him; in affliction, they will seek God early, emphasizing the need for sincere repentance.

questions.question: A believer struggles with obedience to God's commands. What does Hosea 5:11 reveal about the consequences of walking willingly after commandments but still being oppressed?
options: Even willing obedience may face hardship as part of God's judgment.
Obedience guarantees freedom from all oppression.
God does not care about obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: Even willing obedience may face hardship as part of God's judgment.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 shows Ephraim is oppressed and broken because he walked willingly after the commandment, indicating that consequences may come even during discipline to bring correction.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 5 teaches that God withdraws Himself from those who refuse to seek Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:6 clearly states that when they seek the LORD with their flocks and herds, they will not find Him because He has withdrawn Himself, showing God's response to disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 5, God takes no action against Israel and Judah despite their rebellion.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:10-12 reveal God's wrath poured out upon Judah and Ephraim like water, likening His judgment to moth and rottenness, demonstrating active punishment for rebellion.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 5:14 says, 'For I will be unto Ephraim as a _____, and as a young lion to the house of Judah.'
questions.correctAnswer: lion
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states God will be like a lion to Ephraim, symbolizing fierce judgment and removal of protection, emphasizing the consequences of their sin.

questions.question: How does Hosea 5 guide a believer dealing with temptation to forget God’s commands?
options: Remember that God knows all and will judge unfaithfulness.
Temptation is not serious and can be ignored.
God will approve forgetting His commands.
Ignoring God’s commands leads to blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God knows all and will judge unfaithfulness.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:3 says God knows Ephraim and Israel’s unfaithfulness; verses 7 and 14 warn of judgment for betrayal, underscoring the importance of obedience and faithfulness.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels discouraged because they don’t see immediate answers to prayer. What does Hosea 5 teach about God’s timing and seeking Him?
options: God will return when they acknowledge offense and earnestly seek Him.
Prayers are not necessary for God’s attention.
God answers only when it pleases Him with no conditions.
questions.correctAnswer: God will return when they acknowledge offense and earnestly seek Him.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 explains that God waits until His people confess and seek Him; in affliction, they seek Him early, teaching persistence and humility in prayer.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity and honesty can be drawn from Hosea 5’s warning to priests and leaders?
options: Leaders must not be snares or traps to the people but guide them rightly.
Integrity is optional for spiritual leaders.
Deception is acceptable if it benefits the leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must not be snares or traps to the people but guide them rightly.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:1 warns priests and the house of Israel about being a snare and net, emphasizing the responsibility of leaders to uphold integrity and not cause spiritual harm.

questions.question: Based on Hosea 5, how should a believer respond when facing God’s rebuke and discipline?
options: Acknowledge offenses and seek God’s face sincerely.
Ignore the rebuke and continue as before.
Blame others and refuse to repent.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledge offenses and seek God’s face sincerely.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 teaches that God will return when His people acknowledge their offenses and seek Him, highlighting repentance and humility as proper responses.

questions.question: How does Hosea 5 illustrate the importance of spiritual discipline and personal devotion?
options: Failure to know the LORD leads to spiritual whoredoms and defilement.
Spiritual discipline is not important if you attend festivals.
Devotion is only for priests and leaders.
Only outward actions matter, not the spirit.
questions.correctAnswer: Failure to know the LORD leads to spiritual whoredoms and defilement.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:4 explains the spirit of whoredoms is in the midst of them because they have not known the LORD, teaching the need for genuine personal devotion and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: What does Hosea 5 reveal about God's justice and wrath in relation to stewardship and obedience?
options: God pours out wrath on those who remove boundaries and disobey.
Obedience is irrelevant to God's judgment.
God rewards those who remove boundaries.
questions.correctAnswer: God pours out wrath on those who remove boundaries and disobey.
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:10 describes princes of Judah as those who remove the bound, resulting in God's wrath poured out like water, teaching that disobedience in stewardship and leadership brings judgment.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:1, the 'snare on Mizpah' and the 'net spread upon Tabor' metaphorically represent what aspect of Israel's condition?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and impending punishment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:1 uses the imagery of a snare and net to signify a trap or judgment coming upon Israel, indicating impending punishment for their actions.

questions.question: Which phrase in Hosea 5:3 illustrates Israel's spiritual unfaithfulness as 'committing whoredom'?
options: They have not known the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is defiled
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:3 explicitly states that Ephraim commits whoredom and Israel is defiled, portraying their spiritual infidelity.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'the spirit of whoredoms is in the midst of them' in Hosea 5:4 contribute to the chapter's overall theme?
options: It highlights Israel’s persistent idolatry and failure to seek God
It describes a ceremonial ritual of the priests
It refers to a political treaty with Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights Israel’s persistent idolatry and failure to seek God
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:4 metaphorically describes the pervasive idolatry ('spirit of whoredoms') that prevents Israel from turning back to God.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:5, the pride of Israel 'doth testify to his face.' What literary device is primarily used here?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The pride 'testifying to his face' personifies pride as if it were a witness, a literary device emphasizing Israel's arrogance.

questions.question: Hosea 5:6 mentions that Israel will seek the LORD but will not find Him because He has withdrawn. This withdrawal is best understood as what theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine hiddenness as judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:6 illustrates God withdrawing Himself as a form of judgment, a common biblical theme where God hides His face from sinners.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'strange children' mentioned in Hosea 5:7 in the context of Israel's covenant relationship?
options: They symbolize foreign alliances and idolatrous offspring
They refer to literal children from mixed marriages
They indicate the growth of the population
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize foreign alliances and idolatrous offspring
questions.explanation: The phrase 'strange children' in Hosea 5:7 metaphorically indicates the offspring of spiritual adultery and illegitimate alliances contrary to God's covenant.

questions.question: The command to 'Blow ye the cornet in Gibeah, and the trumpet in Ramah' in Hosea 5:8 serves primarily as a call for what?
options: Warning and alarm of impending judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Warning and alarm of impending judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:8 uses the imagery of trumpet blasts as a traditional signal of alarm or warning, indicating coming judgment upon Israel.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 5:9, Ephraim will be desolate on the day of rebuke, and this judgment is uniquely kept secret among the tribes of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:9 states that Ephraim will be desolate on the day of rebuke, and God has made this certain judgment known among the tribes, not kept secret.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:10, the princes of Judah are likened to those who 'remove the bound.' This metaphor primarily critiques their role in:
questions.correctAnswer: Disregarding moral and legal boundaries
questions.explanation: The image of removing the bound in Hosea 5:10 criticizes Judah's leaders for violating established moral and legal limits, inviting divine wrath.

questions.question: Hosea 5:11 says Ephraim is 'oppressed and broken in judgment' because he 'willingly walked after the commandment.' What does this imply about Ephraim's attitude toward God's law?
options: They followed the commandments out of their own will, but still faced consequences
They were ignorant of the commandments
questions.correctAnswer: They followed the commandments out of their own will, but still faced consequences
questions.explanation: The verse suggests Ephraim chose to follow commandments, but perhaps those were man-made or misguided, leading to oppression and judgment.

questions.question: The comparison of Ephraim to a moth and Judah to rottenness in Hosea 5:12 is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:12 uses metaphorical language to depict destruction and decay symbolizing the internal ruin of Ephraim and Judah.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:13, Ephraim’s turning to 'the Assyrian' and 'king Jareb' illustrates what historical or theological theme?
options: Seeking foreign alliances instead of trusting God
A successful military alliance with Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking foreign alliances instead of trusting God
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:13 shows Ephraim turning to Assyria for help, representing misplaced trust in political powers over God, a common prophetic theme.

questions.question: The image of God as a 'lion' and 'young lion' in Hosea 5:14 functions primarily to convey:
options: God’s fierce judgment and power over Israel and Judah
questions.correctAnswer: God’s fierce judgment and power over Israel and Judah
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:14 uses the lion metaphor to emphasize God's strength and the inevitability of His judgment on Israel and Judah.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:15, what condition must Israel meet for God to 'return to [His] place' and restore relationship?
options: They must acknowledge their offense and seek God's face
They must defeat their enemies in battle
They must build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: They must acknowledge their offense and seek God's face
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 states that God will return only when Israel acknowledges their sins and seeks Him earnestly, highlighting repentance as key.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the chiasm structure suggested by Hosea 5:6-10, where Israel’s failure to find God is bracketed by calls to sound the trumpet and warnings of desolation?
options: Judgment begins and ends with public warning, framing Israel’s spiritual failure
A chronological history of Israel’s kings
A prophecy of future exile with no call to repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment begins and ends with public warning, framing Israel’s spiritual failure
questions.explanation: The passage uses a chiasm where the trumpet calls (verses 8 and 10) frame the central theme of God’s withdrawal and Israel’s failure in verses 6-9.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:1, who is called to hear the message of impending judgment?
options: The priests, house of Israel, and house of the king
questions.correctAnswer: The priests, house of Israel, and house of the king
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:1 explicitly calls the priests, the house of Israel, and the house of the king to hear the word of judgment. This reflects God's indictment of both religious and political leadership, consistent with scriptures like Ezekiel 22:26 and Jeremiah 23:1-2 where leaders are held accountable.

questions.question: What is the nature of Israel's sin described in Hosea 5:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Adultery and defilement
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:3 uses the metaphor of whoredom to describe Israel's unfaithfulness to God, indicating spiritual adultery and defilement. This imagery is consistent with Jeremiah 3:8-9 and Ezekiel 16:15 where Israel's covenant unfaithfulness is likened to adultery.

questions.question: Why will Israel and Ephraim fall according to Hosea 5:5?
options: Because of their iniquity and pride
Because of the failure of their kings
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their iniquity and pride
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:5 states that Israel and Ephraim will fall due to their iniquity and the pride of Israel testifying against them. The theme of pride leading to downfall aligns with Proverbs 16:18 and Isaiah 2:12.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:6, what is the reason given for Israel not finding the LORD when they seek Him?
options: Because He has withdrawn Himself from them
Because they seek Him in the wrong places
Because they have not fasted properly
Because the priests have forbidden it
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has withdrawn Himself from them
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:6 reveals that God has withdrawn His presence from Israel, so though they seek Him with their flocks and herds, they will not find Him. This theme of God hiding His face because of sin is echoed in Isaiah 59:2 and Psalm 81:11-12.

questions.question: What does Hosea 5:7 accuse Israel of having done against the LORD?
options: Dealt treacherously and begotten strange children
Built high places and worshiped idols
questions.correctAnswer: Dealt treacherously and begotten strange children
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:7 states Israel has dealt treacherously against the LORD and begotten strange children, symbolizing covenant unfaithfulness and spiritual apostasy. This is consistent with Jeremiah 7:9 and Ezekiel 23:30 where betrayal of God is likened to adultery and producing illegitimate offspring.

questions.question: What is the significance of the cornet and trumpet being blown in Hosea 5:8?
options: To sound an alarm of impending judgment
To call the people to worship
questions.correctAnswer: To sound an alarm of impending judgment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:8 commands the blowing of the cornet and trumpet as a call to alarm and warning of coming judgment. This use of trumpets as instruments of warning is consistent with Numbers 10:9 and Joel 2:1.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:10, why will God's wrath be poured out upon the princes of Judah?
options: Because they remove the bound, acting unjustly
questions.correctAnswer: Because they remove the bound, acting unjustly
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:10 condemns the princes of Judah for removing the boundary lines, a metaphor for perverting justice and violating property rights. This accusation aligns with Micah 2:2 and Ezekiel 22:27 which condemn leaders for injustice.

questions.question: What is the metaphor used in Hosea 5:12 for God's judgment against Ephraim and Judah?
options: A moth to Ephraim and rottenness to Judah
A flood to wash away their sins
questions.correctAnswer: A moth to Ephraim and rottenness to Judah
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:12 uses the metaphors of a moth consuming Ephraim and rottenness consuming Judah, illustrating destructive judgment that eats away at them internally. This metaphor is similar to Isaiah 51:8 and Job 13:28 where destructive agents symbolize judgment.

questions.question: What action did Ephraim take when they saw their sickness and Judah saw their wound, according to Hosea 5:13?
options: They sought help from the Assyrian king Jareb
They repented and sought the LORD
They built altars to foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: They sought help from the Assyrian king Jareb
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:13 describes Ephraim and Judah turning to the Assyrian king Jareb for healing instead of God, highlighting their misplaced trust. This act of seeking foreign alliances rather than divine deliverance is condemned in Isaiah 30:1-2 and Psalm 20:7.

questions.question: What is God's described role toward Ephraim and Judah in Hosea 5:14?
options: A lion tearing and taking away without rescue
questions.correctAnswer: A lion tearing and taking away without rescue
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:14 portrays God as a lion and young lion who will tear Ephraim and Judah and take them away with no one to rescue them, symbolizing fierce judgment. Similar imagery is found in Amos 3:8 and Revelation 5:5 where the lion represents divine power and judgment.

questions.question: According to Hosea 5:15, under what condition will God return to His place and later come back to His people?
options: When they acknowledge their offense and seek His face
When they build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: When they acknowledge their offense and seek His face
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:15 states that God will withdraw until they confess their sin and seek Him. This conditional restoration aligns with 2 Chronicles 7:14 and Jeremiah 29:13 where repentance leads to God's favor.

questions.question: How does Hosea 5:4 describe Israel's spiritual condition and their knowledge of the LORD?
options: They have a spirit of whoredoms and have not known the LORD
They are humble and seek God earnestly
questions.correctAnswer: They have a spirit of whoredoms and have not known the LORD
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:4 indicates that Israel's spirit is characterized by whoredoms (idolatry) and a lack of true knowledge of the LORD. This spiritual ignorance is similar to Jeremiah 9:13 and Romans 1:21 where rejection of God is linked to moral corruption.

questions.question: What does Hosea 5:11 say is the reason for Ephraim being oppressed and broken in judgment?
options: Because he willingly walked after the commandment
questions.correctAnswer: Because he willingly walked after the commandment
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:11 reveals a paradox where Ephraim is broken in judgment because he willingly followed the commandment, implying a willful rebellion or misguided obedience. This paradox reflects themes in Isaiah 5:24 and Romans 1:32 where persistent rejection leads to judgment.

questions.question: In Hosea 5:9, what is said about Ephraim in the day of rebuke?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim shall be desolate
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:9 declares Ephraim will be desolate when rebuked, indicating judgment and ruin. This desolation corresponds with prophetic warnings in Jeremiah 30:6 and Ezekiel 37:11 about the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What does Hosea 5:2 teach about God's attitude towards the revolters who commit slaughter?
options: God has been a rebuker of them all
questions.correctAnswer: God has been a rebuker of them all
questions.explanation: Hosea 5:2 states that although the revolters are skilled in slaughter, God has consistently rebuked them, showing His disapproval of their actions. This theme of divine rebuke of wickedness is found in Psalm 7:11 and Proverbs 3:12.
